title: Cat. 67  Love Cup, 1900
publication_title: American Silver in the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Tiffany & Co. (American, founded 1837)  
New York, New York  
Silver and copper; 31.8 × 21.8 × cm (12 1/2 × 8 5/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, restricted gift of Mrs. Harold T. Martin, 1978.442

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">This resplendent love cup—also commonly called a loving cup—stands as a testament to Tiffany & Co.’s production of opulent, labor-intensive presentation silver and reflects the persistence of Neoclassicism at the turn of the twentieth century. In both form and decoration, the vessel is derived from classical prototypes interpreted for Tiffany’s Gilded Age clientele.

Although Tiffany wares kept pace with the late nineteenth-century taste for exoticism, which often involved the adoption of non-Western aesthetics and techniques, classical revival remained one of the most widely embraced styles in silver design. The 1893 World’s Columbian Exposition greatly influenced America’s continued appetite for Neoclassical aesthetics; the entire architectural program evoked the grandeur of ancient Greece and Rome, and many of the exhibitors’ designs fell in line with the celebratory historicism of the fair’s plan. The Tiffany exhibition—among the largest and most glamorous of all the displays—was dominated by revivalist styles. Indeed, company literature described the general character of the jewelry on display as an “exhaustive study of all the earlier periods.”

Tiffany’s interpretation of classical precedents carried on into the twentieth century. In some cases, classical designs were applied to newer, innovative forms; in others, both form and ornamentation were rooted in ancient models. This cup, which has also been referred to as a “wine cooler” because of its size and presumed use, exemplifies the latter approach to Neoclassical silver. The bell-shaped body, ribbed belly, and handles that scroll up under the lip relate directly to ancient Apulian kraters (bowls for mixing wine and water) made in southern Italy in the fourth to third centuries B.C., an example can be found in the collection of famed Tiffany designer Edward C. Moore (see cats. 58–59) at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York. Furthermore, the grape-and-vine design applied over its etched-copper body, the naturalistic leaf decoration and egg-and-dart motif at the rim and neck of the base, and the beaded borders repeated at the top and bottom of the ribbing have antecedents in the decorative schemes of ancient ceramic vessels. Even the copper color recalls the rich terra-cotta hue of classical pottery.

Order no. 3138 and pattern no. 14478, this cup is the last of a series of such objects produced by the firm in 1900. While no reference to its designer exists (although it has been suggested that George Paulding Farnham (see cat. 66), Tiffany’s chief designer at the time, was responsible), company ledgers identify Clarence Gardner of the Forest Hills Newark Factory as working on the vessel along with four other silversmiths designated only by their last names: Indel, Baron, Autui, and Richlui. The manufacturing cost for execution and chasing was $267 (over $7,000 in today’s terms), an amount suggesting a significant degree of handwork even with the plant overhead factored in.

It comes as no surprise, then, that this lavish object marked the wedding of two individuals of great familial wealth and prestige, Marcellus Hartley Dodge (1881–1963), heir to the Remington Arms fortune, and Ethel Geraldine Rockefeller (1882–1973), daughter of financier William Rockefeller and niece to John D. Rockefeller. Despite the gap between the 1900 date of completion and the couple’s nuptials on April 18, 1907, the inscription bearing their initials confirms the pair’s initial ownership of the work; the cup remained in the family’s possession until the sale of Mrs. Dodge’s estate in 1975.  
Elizabeth McGoey

The other names appear in the entry for this order number in other company records: Indel worked on the body; Baron and Autui, the handles; and Richlui is also listed but without his role specified. The retail value of this specific cup is unknown, but Tiffany records suggest that large chased or etched loving cups from this period would have cost between $300 and $1,500 (from $8,500 to over $40,000 in present-day sums).
